posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28052542
>Marriage is not necessary for commitment
Yes, it is, or at least some kind of structure is. Marriage is the social institution that's provided the structure for millennia, so I'll stick with that.

> it's very telling of you though that you think commitment is only possible in marriage
You're using commitment in a different sense than I am:
To you, it is being dedicated to one course of action or another. It's a subjective feeling. Important for a good marriage, obviously, but it's not measurable and it's certainly not consistent.
Moral standards are designed to be both. That's how they work.
This is why I use commitment in the objective sense: being bound to a course of action by *external* forces. Marriage is (and should be) the mechanism by which commitment is standardized and enforced. Things like infidelity or abandonment can be punished if someone breaks their commitment only in this formal sense. The only thing that happens if they break their subjective feeling of commitment is a guilty conscience.

Basically, what you're saying is that laws aren't necessary because some--even most--people wouldn't do erstwhile prohibited things by their nature. Or that guardrails on a cliffside road aren't necessary because most people are good drivers. This is fallacious reasoning. It replaces standards which both guide behavior and protect against negative consequences with pure fatalism, simply waiting until things happen for better or worse and then calling them good or bad after the fact. A lack of any formal commitment works just fine, like with your couples--until the moment it doesn't. Then that lack of commitment shows, and the damage is much greater because you ignored insurance on the assumption you wouldn't need it.

tl;dr Saying you're above rules because you wouldn't break them is hubris. Society needs them, and if you wouldn't break them anyway, it wouldn't hurt you to set a good example.

>>28053081
>christ outside of the church?
This isn't possible. You cannot have Christ without the church; or the church without Christ. I know well enough what you mean though, OP. Worldly church politics sucks and many church organizations contradict Christ often. It's no wonder why you do not have love for the concept of 'church'.
It's important to understand what 'church' means, what it is, and how it ought to function.

The 'church' is Christ's work; it's his impact on humanity, it's his bride, his passion. The church is the mystical body of Christ himself. In other words, WE are the church. Those who believe in Christ and follow Christ are collectively the 'church'. In order to follow Christ, to embody him, is to become a 'Christian'. To do as Christ did, to live as he did, to love as he loved. This requires fellowship, commune, being a brother to others. This necessitates church.

You can get into Christianity on your own, and many (including myself) have. You can start by praying and talking with God, Christ, and the Spirit privately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28050326
How old are you guys? How old were you when you started dating? Relationships that start in their early twenties are rarely destined for their late twenties due to how much people change and how interests change. Do you guys see the world? Do you get up to activities? Try new things?
The hard truth is when you've been dating as long as you have, the people involved have to make the decision to push forward with the relationship even as their early attraction has faded (difficult/uncomfortable), or to split (easier). It sounds like she's chosen the second option and may have already started to develop feelings for other people. Remember that people don't just decide to break up one day, they think about it for a long time, often over 6+ months. By the time you get the news that your relationship is in trouble, it's often too late as a result. If she's not will to talk about it and her mind is made up, there's very little you can do.

Make a budget, figure out how much you have, what percentage you'd like to put towards a vacation and then look at what type and which location you'd like to hit. If it's super expensive but you really want to do it, then it's a special goal. But if you math it all out and it still sounds too expensive, you probably won't enjoy it even I'd you go.

Keep in mind, you deserve to rest. You've made the money, you have the vacation time, you deserve to spend those resources on something you want to enjoy.

Caveat: don't think of travel as a panacea or something that you do to be more cool or attractive or whatever, because it just makes you another blowhard influencer type trying to show off how cool his life is. Go and do things because they're special and enjoyable to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28053049
This is a pattern found in individuals with autism, despite popular belief on this website it can impact people in a wide variety of ways and a lot of people mask well but struggle in other areas. It isn't uncommon for some autistic people to really struggle with emotional range and/or emotional empathy. Cognitive empathy is more tricky because there's obviously the difference in communication and experience, so it may be there for some but conditional on their specific framework of understanding.

Consider anything else that makes you uncomfortable or especially comfortable. Routines, sensory preferences, times where you have thought in rigid ways, times where you've totally missed the mark but somehow gotten away with it, things you spend a lot of time focusing on, weird "aha!" moments and obviously early signs like behavioural issues, being especially quiet and withdrawn, struggling with food, certain clothes or certain places.

If you do have autism and you've been raised in an environment where you're accepted and it doesn't cause you too many problems then I'd just accept it if I were you. Carry on doing what works for you.

Some people are just born with low emotional range and it develops more as they age.

I'm sorry to hear that, you clearly suffer with a lot of anxiety and I'm hoping that as you get older that will subside. I think so, yes. Especially for university if you're going, it means if you're ever in crisis you can have adjustments. The same with work. Not only that but it's validating and whoever diagnoses you could refer you to professionals that will help in ways you might not have expected.

It's your life and you deserve to get the best out of it that you can, there's lots of information out there for you too.

posts.com: Burned myself a couple weeks ago and one of the burns appears to be infected. Unfortunately I'm American and the only medical facility open is the ER. Will I die if I wait a couple hours for prompt care to open so I don't spend $1000 out of pocket at the ER?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28053231
If you do not have fever no, but you have to keep it clean: wash it twice a day and keep it absolutely dry, plus you should take some antibiotics, e.g. amoxicillin + clavulanic acid for a few days

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28053242
Does keeping it dry mean I should dry off any antibiotic or antiseptic I put on it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28053265
no no, antibiotics - you should take pills. antibiotic cream is the second choice.

What I mean is: clean the wound wih antiseptic (eg. chlorhexidine), rinse it thoroughly ("the solution to pollution is dilution!" as the rhyme says) and dry it with clean gauzes, then dress it: ideally you want over the skin
- something non-sticking like a silicon dressing eg. mepitel, or stuff like bactigras/inadine
- gauze
- some coverage eg. cosmopore or anything really

do it twice a day

However just cleaning it regularly and keeping dry with gauzes is still good. Not perfect, but good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
depends on the reason. people are different. generally it gets worse, but you get to a stage of acceptance and regret.

if you go alone simply to avoid judgment from other people or due to self-perceived inadequacy, the loneliness serves only to reinforce your negative self-views. it's a feedback loop where the lack of experiences serves as evidence that no one wants to be around you, thus you isolate more, reinforcing that line of thought. it gets worse and worse, and you lose the naive hope that things will get better with time. as you get older, you aren't forced into random situations in which you befriend other people. you aren't forced into school, co-workers rarely want to socialize, etc. that hope you once had slowly just evaporates. You get more numb past a point. You may get to a point of not caring, but that's more a point of acceptance and regret that you cannot rekindle the old embers of dying friendships and things as you are too old or too far gone.

if you are a loner simply due to you enjoying being alone then you likely eventually stop caring sooner. your regrets are less. very few people genuinely appreciate being truly alone. humans are a social species, thus it goes against their nature. often that joy of being alone is simply masking the desire to be away from other people potentially evaluating you negatively or to get a small break of peace. They don't value the loneliness, they value the solitude. some people desire a bit of solitude more than others, but they often don't want it entirely (even in cases of severe schizoid type behaviors). hard to tell the difference between people at the surface, as the end behaviors are the same but the underlying reasoning maybe different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28052737
This.
I work for state run mental health services. If you call they'll try to set up a time for you to complete an assessment with them. If you walk in early, you might be able to have one done that day. At most they'll give you a diagnosis, set you up with a psychiatrist to get the proper meds and most likely a therapist. Depending on how understaffed/ underfunded the place is, these appointments can be a few months out in the worst case. To get "hauled off" You would have to be an immediate danger to yourself or others. To the point where you have a viable plan that you are ready and willing to follow through on at that moment.
I understand the paranoia makes actually going in to talk to someone a bitch and a half, but getting the diagnosis and taking the proper steps towards recovery really is the best option.

The 4chan view of transgender people isn’t going to be of much help. It’s all cookie cutter behavior responses memes etc. here. But I was in a similar situation only I’m bi and I just didn’t think I could have ended up with a trans guy (I was wrong)

I guess my advice for you is this although my bf is still the only trans person I know:

Their identity and experience with that identity is deeply personal to them and you should probably be thankful if they share with you that experience. It’s a sign of vulnerability unless they are just open with everyone. Listen and if it’s hard to understand even putting yourself in their shoes it’s okay but listen.

Use their preferred pronouns it’s pretty simple but important.

You may be curious about it and that’s fair but they’ve probably changed their name and their old name will probably be a source of pain. Depends on the individual but try to see their chosen name as the one to know them by and care about.

It could help to know what their plans are with their transition because that could affect your ability to stay together. However keep in mind that those choices are for them alone to make and attempting to influence it could only lead to resentment. Evaluate if you are compatible and give them your support.

Unfortunately this is an era of great turmoil for trans people. They’re hated and discriminated against and many now face politicians looking to remove their access to care. It’s likely very hard on them to live in that world and see it.

Realize that it may seem a lot but these are just people like everyone else. If you feel love for them it’s okay and doesn’t necessarily mean your own identity is changing. Like the questions of “am I just gay” or whatever like from my end I know there’ll be people who think I’m just in a straight relationship with a woman but I know better. It is strange but that doesn’t take away from anything. I love my boyfriend and can’t see myself with anyone else.

>>28052811
The problem with this is that what people think they want and what they actually do want are often two different things.

For example, I used to do the dating app thing a lot when I was younger, and there's a type of girl you frequently encounter on there who says "I'm really scared of meeting face to face, can we talk online for a while first?" So of course I always said yes, and talked; but absolutely every time the end result was that I got ghosted - sometimes after investing many months of time in her. Eventually I realised that if a girl isn't willing to meet face to face within 7 days (and assuming there isn't any logistical reason why she can't!) it's never going to happen.

What makes this kind of thing difficult is that all of them (and I'm talking maybe 200 women here, over a number of years) all of them genuinely believed that talking online would result in them becoming comfortable enough to meet face to face; and in absolutely every case they were wrong; they never got comfortable enough.

So, in the same way, if you told me that you were really interested in me but needed time to get comfortable, my assumption would be that you genuinely believed that was true, but that you were mistaken, and that there was no chance you would *ever* become comfortable with me. So I would move on and let you find someone you actually do like.

I'm a self taught classical guitarist. I practiced a shit ton (sometimes like 4-6 hours a day) because I absolutely loved it. i've That's the key. I've only been playing for 1.5 years, but I'm better than most people who have played for 5+ years because I've practiced so much. If I were you, I would try to start by learning the spanish/flamenco piece Malaguena. It sounds so cool and can be as easy or technical as you want it to be.

If you start with classical guitar, acoustic guitar will come easy but Electric will be a completely different beast all together. I would advise you to start on which ever style/type of guitar you want to ultimately play. The style of fingerstyle guitar does not translate well to electric rhythm playing, although you will be much better than someone starting from nothing.

Good luck and have fun!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28047799
I learned most of my guitar from JustinGuitar and Martymusic on YouTube. From these resources you'll be able to learn chords, which you can use to learn songs you like. Eventually you'll want to learn music theory, which you can learn for free on the internet as well. Getting guitar lessons might be beneficial too since a teacher can tell you what to work on and whether or not you've even improved.

Yes you'll be able to play acoustic from a classical, they're pretty much the same, the strings are a different material so they produce a slightly different sound. The latter's also used for certain type of music that an acoustic isn't used for. Electric guitars have 6 strings, you must be thinking of a bass. You can apply most of your former knowledge onto electric guitar, such as chords and what not, but the electric guitar offers much more opportunities for more sound. You'll be looking at different genres of music, like rock, and you'll be able to fiddle with guitar pedals and amp settings and what not to produce sounds that you couldn't with an acoustic or classical.

When I first started learning guitar it took me around a week to learn one chord. Progress was slow, and I spent at least 30 min - hr, sometimes more learning new things because the feeling of making progress was such an addicting one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28047799
haha finally a post I can be useful on!

Ive been playing guitar for 5+ years and studying with 2 teachers for 3+ on classical. I would recommend starting with ' Julio S. Sagreras Guitar Lessons: Books 1-3 ' and ' The Segovia Scales: Illustrated with Standard Notation, Tablature, and Fretboard Diagrams' Most of your study should be done with the First book and use the second book for your warmups. You will also need a tuner and a foot stool or support of somekind. I use a cheap On stage FS7850B. Its been working well for a couple years now. If you have a particularly long torso or something you can also pick up a ergoplay but try out the footstool first. You need a tuner too but I just use guitar tuna on my phone.

It is very very important to stretch your arms,wrists,fingers and warmup before playing and practicing do NOT skip this part I learned the hard way. You only need to practice 15 or 30 min a day starting. Make sure you have your fingering and posture down perfectly you need to have a very strong foundation on proper fingering and technique.

You do not need to take lessons books and youtube is more than enough if you do not plan on going pro I recommend 'This is Classical Guitar' on YouTube.

I cant think of much else but if I do I will reply to my post. also listen to dis song :DDD. Francisco Tárrega is super cool and later on you might want to get ' The Francisco Tarrega Collection ' book. Just please get a strong foundation and learn to read notes first. Tabs are good but please dont only use them.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R-5weyHVC2U

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RPdfbaNB7jg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocHYfOZk_pk

honestly just spend time with the instrument in your hands. i mean a fuckton of time. like don't sit the thing down. push yourself in terms of technique. learn scales mostly. and yes you should learn to read sheet music. but mostly just focus on engaging with the instrument and the music on a deeper level and you'll just naturally improve. most people don't do this they just remain indifferent and expect to learn like it's mathematics or something. they don't develop a deep personal connection to the movements, the sounds, the little nuances of dynamics. i've played guitar my whole life and it's cringe when i see ppl trying to learn but instead of just putting their soul into it they do a bunch of exercises and end up with an utterly generic sound, no dynamics, no articulation, relying on different pedals and amps to get the sound they want... it's sad.

posts.com:
You haven't been through anything with her, and you never loved her. These statements are 100% true whether you agree or not, and the reason they are true is because you don't actually know her. She's in the middle east while you're in oz or nz.

Her "her life aspirations and careful planning" are to move from the middle east to a developed country. She chose the new guy because he's in yankville and she thankfully views that as a more aspirational place to live. That's great news because you dodged a bullet, and oceania doesn't need that kind if people.

I understand you think you felt something for her, but what you feel for is a idealised fantasy in your head that you've overlayed onto her to make up all the gaps in things about her you don't know. The little quirks of behaviour, the way she smells, how she acts when she's not in a disembodied conversation. You don't know a person until you've spent consistent time with them in person and developed a bond through shared experiences.

Not in an online game or some such, real life experience good and bad. Hugged when something's gone wrong, laughed together when something's amusing, been places together.

If you want someone, find them irl not online. Not through stupid apps, not through discord, not through a video games, not using a computer at all. Real life, by getting up and putting yourself into social situations. Find someone within 20 minutes travel of you. Make friends, find a girl, take her places, share experiences together.

posts.com:
>>28051505
What makes the human happy is nothing. Not in the negative sense, but in the positive sense -- you can happy anywhere, with a few exceptions that don't apply to you. So nothing makes you happy, you simply are.

Happiness is the natural state of the human being. If you see video of isolated tribesmen in the Amazon or Indonesia or Africa living a stone age existence they are smiling and happy, assuming basic needs of food and shelter are met.

Society lies to you and says pleasure and comfort seeking are happiness when they are completely unrelated. In fact quite the opposite, pinning your hopes on pleasure and comfort and being entertained adds barriers between you and this natural state of happiness.

NOTE this does NOT mean sell all your possessions and move to the Amazon, because this again would be setting up happiness as a "thing" you can "do" just substituting chasing one -ism for another.

You can be happy RIGHT NOW and you have all that you need. You have a career, money, and job -- so keep them and enjoy them since why not they have come into your hand, just realize they have nothing to do with happiness. Live every moment in peace doing whatever it is that you were already doing and already going to do.

So what is there to do? Nothing. Simply observe the moments of your life as you live them, which will happen with or without your participation. And then you will be happy, because you already are.

Refusing to be emotionally vulnerable in a romantic relationship not only will destroy the relationship, but it is a sign of weakness. Your partner will see you as weak for NOT being emotionally vulnerable.

That isn't an open invitation to constantly complain or mope, being a cry baby isn't emotional vulnerability. Likewise, if you're depressed you have no business starting a new relationship which includes continuing a new casual relationship where things haven't become serious yet.

In short, you should be emotionally well adjusted before you try to get into a relationship. If you haven't achieved that step, you're not ready for a relationship yet.
